State of Michigan
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RICK SNYDER NICK LYON
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 22, 2018
Irene Waller
Tuscola County DHS
1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
RE: License #: CP790201478
Tuscola County DHS
1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
Dear Mrs. Waller:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 1/22/18.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and ISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
James B. Gale, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 296-4814
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Three of eight reevaluations reviewed were not completed at
least 15 days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who have
children placed in the home shall be notified there is a
corrective action plan and what is required of the foster
parent in that plan.
In one of two special evaluations reviewed there was no
documentation that the assigned social worker was provided
with a copy of the corrective action plan.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency,
and the other parties involved in providing needed
services, or medical care, unless the agency documents
why any of the entities have not been involved.
In two of twelve service plans reviewed there was not adequate
documentation that the child’s parent was involved in the
development of the service plan.
4

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.33(c) Page 28 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s supervisor, the
parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include an explanation
of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to
secure their participation in services.
In four of twelve service plans reviewed the birth parents did not sign a PATP. In one of
three service plans requiring a child’s signature it was not obtained. This is also a DHHS
Policy FOM 722-08c requirement.
Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and service agreement, the
parent is given a copy for review. Foster care workers need to ensure the parent
understands all areas within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the PATP,
foster care workers must identify and document additional action needed to secure
the parent’s and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance with
the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or expanded, the updated PATP will
reflect this process. Parents and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for opportunity to evaluate
their progress towards completing goals.
In four of twelve service plans reviewed the birth parents did not sign a PATP. In one of
three service plans requiring a child’s signature it was not obtained. This is also an ISEP
6.33 c requirement.
The foster parent is required to sign each parent agency treatment plan.
In four of twelve service plans reviewed there was no documentation the foster parent
signed the PATP.
5

DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Page 10 CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)/
GUARDIAN(S)
During the first month of out of home placement the case manager must have two
face to face contacts with each parent at least one must be at the parent’s
residence.
In two separate cases the assigned case manager did not clearly document efforts to
make a home call to the parent’s residence.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H – Unannounced Home Visit .CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in the caregiver’s home
each calendar month. If there are two caregivers, such as a primary and secondary
caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the secondary
caregiver in the home at least once each quarter. The caseworker must make an
unannounced visit to the home every quarter. The unannounced visit must be
documented in MiSACWIS.
In two of eight service plan periods requiring an unannounced home visit the requirement
was not met.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must be provided to
the foster parent within two weeks of the child’s placement.
The initial medical passport in two of seven cases reviewed was not provided timely to
the care givers to meet the two week requirement of this rule.
.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
6

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
Renewal Inspection 1/11/17
The following rule, policy and ISEP citations were made as a result of the renewal
inspection.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
The agency’s two borrowed bed documentation did not comply
with this rule. A corrective active action plan is required.
This renewal inspection reviewed four borrowed bed files
and found the agency in compliance.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
The agency’s two borrowed bed documentation did not comply
with this rule. A corrective action plan is required.
This renewal inspection reviewed four borrowed bed files
and found the agency in compliance.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
7

The agency’s two borrowed bed documentation did not comply
with this rule. A corrective action plan is required.
This renewal inspection reviewed four borrowed bed files
and found the agency in compliance.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
The agency’s two borrowed bed documentation did not comply
with this rule. A corrective action plan is required.
This renewal inspection reviewed four borrowed bed files
and found the agency in compliance.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
The agency’s two borrowed bed documentation did not comply
with this rule. A corrective action plan is required.
This renewal inspection reviewed four borrowed bed files
and found the agency in compliance.
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary
tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
8

The agency at the time of this renewal inspection did not have all case related
documents uploaded in MiSACWIS as required. A corrective action plan is required.
This renewal inspection found that in the records reviewed the agency was
compliant with this requirement.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
The information contained in the DCWL analyst’s (1/31/18) report was collected
through the interviews of randomly selected families that were working with Tuscola
DHHS between the dates of 11/29/17 – 1/24/18. The following came up as a concerns
during these interviews. This consultant reviewed all related records and interviewed
assigned case managers and supervisors to address all concerns.
Concern:
A foster parent doesn’t have a medical passport for the children that are currently
placed in the foster home. At the time of the home visit, the children had been in the
home for one week.
Resolution:
A review of the records and interview with the assigned case manager determined that
3 of the four children in this home did not have a medical passsport. These children
were subsequently replaced. The assigned case manager provided the new foster
parent with medical passports the 3 children.
Concern:
An unlicensed relative family has two foster youth in the home. The children are
sleeping on mattresses on the floor.
Resolution:
The foster care records were reviewed and interviewes were conducted the the
assigned case manager and supervisor. This concern could not be verified and the
children were subsequently replaced.
Concern:
Three birth parents indicated they aren’t allowed to take part in decisions which involves
their children's educational and medical needs and physical appearance.
Resolution:
A review of the children’s records and interviews with the assigned case manager did
not verify this complaint. This consultant did cite the agency for not clearly documenting
9

that two of the birth parents were engaged in the development of their initial service
plans.
Concern:
One birth parent reported she isn’t familiar with the case service plan. This same parent
also indicated that she doesn’t receive proper notification of court hearings.
Resolution:
As indicated above the agency did not clearly document that two of three birth parents
were engaged in the development of their initial service plans. One parent’s complaint
that she didn’t recevie proper notification of court hearings was not verified.
Concern:
A birth parent reported he hasn’t received financial assistance or information regarding
available resources for housing. The parent stated the agency is requesting him to
obtain stable housing, but they will not provide any assistance with this goal. The
parent also informed that it took the agency 3-4 month's to schedule parenting time with
his children.
Resolution:
Interviews were conducted with the assigned case manager and supervisor. The foster
care record was reviewed. This consultant cited the agency related to this case for not
clearly documenting the engagement of the birth parent in the development of his initial
service plan. The birth father’s engagment was documented in later service plans by
the assigned case manager.
Concern:
One unlicensed relative family has a bedroom in their basement. The basement does
not have an egress windows.
Concern:
The family reported to the analyst they have a waiver and have no intention to become
licensed. The waiver was approved by Tuscola County DHHS on 11/2/17. This
information was verified via MiSACWIS.
Concern:
An unlicensed relative family has a bedroom in the basement with no egress window.
Resolution:
The family showed the analyst their emergency escape plan. Each household member
can exit from the bedroom windows. The agency verified this plan. The size of the
escape window is 27 inches by 12 inches verified 12/21/17.
10

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
3/28/18
________________________________________
James B. Gale Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 29, 2018
